<font face="Lucida Grande">Click Next to begin the survey.</font>

Welcome to the Patient Preferences to Prevent Neonatal Herpes Survey.



Thank you for your participation!
<font face="Lucida Grande">When you're ready to start, click Next (the right arrow) to begin!</font>

Objectives



  • This presentation will give you information about herpes in adults and newborn babies.


  • One way to prevent herpes in newborn babies is to have a Cesarean delivery.


  • You will learn how herpes can affect a baby and how Cesarean delivery can affect you.


  • After viewing this presentation, a study investigator will ask you your preferences to prevent neonatal herpes.
<font face="Lucida Grande">When you're ready to start, click Next (the right arrow) to begin!</font>
<font face="Lucida Grande"><font size="+7">Before we get started, we need a little information about you.</font></font>
<font face="Lucida Grande">When you're ready to start, click Next (the right arrow) to begin!</font>

What type of provider do you see for your pregnancy?

<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>

<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>

<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>

<font face="Lucida Grande">Thanks for your responses. Click the next arrow to continue the presentation.</font>
What is your marital status?
Which best describes your race/ethnicity?
What is your annual household income?

What is Herpes?



Herpes is caused by a virus (HSV). There are two types:
  • HSV-1 can cause sores around the mouth such as cold sores.
  • HSV-2 can cause sores on the vulva, vagina, or penis (the genitals).


In pregnancy genital herpes is important because the virus can infect the baby during vaginal delivery.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

How Common is Herpes?

About 1 in 4 pregnant women
test positive for HSV-2, the
commonest cause of genital herpes.

The box to the right shows 100 squares.
Yellow squares show the number of women
who test positive for HSV-2.




Up to 90% of pregnant women with genital herpes do not know that they have herpes.

const.name: textCaption
const.value: About 1 in 4 pregnant women test positive for HSV-2.

module.const: <font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

How Do You Get Genital Herpes?



There are two types:
  • You get genital herpes from sexual contact with somebody who has herpes on his/her mouth or genitals.

  • You can be infected with herpes even when your partner does not have sores or does not know that he/she has herpes.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

Genital Herpes may look like this:












Or, there may be NO symptoms or sores.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

How Can Genital Herpes Hurt Your Baby?



If the baby contacts the herpes virus as he/she passes through the birth canal at delivery, the baby could become infected.


Neonatal herpes might make your baby very sick and possibly cause death or complications like cerebral palsy.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

If Your Baby Gets Neonatal Herpes, How Sick Will He/She Be?

The baby would need immediate hospitalization for blood tests, spinal tap and intravenous medication for at least 14 days.
With treatment:
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

const.name: textCaption
const.value: 50% of babies do well and are normal.

module.const: Examples of Infants with Neonatal Herpes
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

Summary of Herpes



  • About 25% of women have genital herpes.
  • About 2% of women get herpes while pregnant.
  • Most people with herpes do not know that they have herpes.
  • It is possible to give your baby herpes at the time of delivery if you have genital herpes.
  • Babies with herpes need immediate hospitalization and treatment.
  • Even with treatment, the baby may have long term problems or die.

const.name: textCaption
const.value: About 25% of women have genital herpes.

const.name: textCaption
const.value: About 2% of women get herpes while pregnant.

module.const: <font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

What is Recommended to Prevent Neonatal Herpes?



Currently, one method to prevent neonatal herpes is Cesarean delivery for women with genital sores at the time of labor.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

What is a Cesarean Delivery?



  • Delivery of the baby through an incision in the abdomen.
  • It is the most common surgery performed in the United States.
  • About 22% of all deliveries in the United States are by Cesarean.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

Incision on the Skin
For Cesarean delivery, an incision is made on the skin.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

Incision on the Uterus
Then an incision is made on the uterus.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

What are the Risks of Cesarean Delivery?

  • Longer recovery time than vaginal delivery.
    • - 3 days in hospital vs. 1 day - Narcotic pain medications needed - 6 weeks of decreased activity
  • Possible short term respiratory problems of the newborn.
    • Possible infection of uterus or skin. Risk up to 15%, Treatment is intravenous antibiotics Possible blood loss causing anemia. 1% will require a blood transfusion

<font face="Lucida Grande"> <font size="+2"> Possible blood clots in your lungs. Risk 7 in 1000
Possible injury to internal organs. Risk 1 in 1000 </font>
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

What are the Long-Term Effects of Cesarean Delivery?

  • More likely to have a Cesarean delivery in your next pregnancy.
  • 1% chance of uterine rupture during labor in your next pregnancy.






  • Increased risk of having problems with your placenta in future pregnancies that could cause complications such as bleeding.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

What are the Benefits of Cesarean Delivery?

  • No episiotomy or vaginal tear during vaginal delivery.
  • May be less likely to have leakage of urine with cough or sneeze than women with vaginal deliveries.
  • Decreases (but does not completely eliminate) the risk of neonatal herpes in women with genital herpes at the time of labor.
  • A woman who has had one Cesarean delivery can still try to have a vaginal delivery with the next pregnancy
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

To Review

  • Neonatal herpes is rare but can cause death or long term problems.
  • Neonatal herpes can occur if herpes virus is present in the birth canal at the time of vaginal delivery.
  • One way to prevent neonatal herpes is Cesarean delivery for women with genital sores during labor.
  • Cesarean delivery has some risks to the mother and may not always prevent neonatal herpes.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

Risk Visualizer

This tool is designed to help you understand and appreciate small risks. Imagine you are in a stadium with 10,000 people. A few of the people have a special ticket. The binoculars allow you to look around the stadium and see the people who have the special ticket. These people are shown in red. Imagine that 10 of the 10,000 (0.1%) people in the stadium got the special ticket. Take a look around and see what this looks like. After you've done that, let's change the percentage of people who have the tickets and see what this looks like. Click the plus button a few times until 800 of 10,000 people have special tickets (8%). Now take a look around and see what this looks like.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

Preference Assessment: Cesarean to Prevent Neonatal HSV
Suppose that you have genital herpes sores at the time of labor. How likely does it need to be for the baby to get herpes if delivered vaginally for you to choose a Cesarean delivery?

To illustrate various risks, take a look at the stadium and choose a risk level. If there are 10,000 pregnant women with genital herpes sores in labor in this stadium, and all of them delivered their babies vaginally, the number of faces in red will have babies with neonatal herpes. Choose the risk level at which you would rather have a Cesarean delivery than risk having a baby with neonatal herpes by using the plus and minus arrows.

What Is The Chance That You Will Have A Baby With Neonatal Herpes?

That depends on if you have genital herpes or if you get herpes while you are pregnant. It is much more common for women who first get herpes during pregnancy to infect their babies.

  • Women who get newly infected with genital herpes at the end of pregnancy have up to a 50% chance of infecting the baby.
  • Women who have been infected with genital herpes before pregnancy, or early in pregnancy, have up to a 4% chance of infecting the baby at delivery.

The most reliable way to know if you have herpes, or if you are at risk to get herpes from your partner, is by a blood test.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>

Preference Assessment: Blood Test to Detect Herpes

An accurate blood test for herpes exists. Please select a response to the following statements
<font face="Lucida Grande" size="+3">I would want <u>my blood tested</u> to see if I have herpes as part of my routine prenatal care. </font>
<font face="Lucida Grande" size="+3">I would want <u>my partner's blood tested</u> to see if he/she has herpes. </font>

const.name: questionStart

module.const: <font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>
Preference Assessment: Acyclovir in Pregnancy

Suppose that you are tested for HSV and find out that you are infected with HSV-2.
The chance that you would infect your baby at the time of delivery is about 2/10,000 (0.02%). The stadium to the right shows the chances of 2 in 10,000.

<font face="Lucida Grande" size="+4">A medication exists that is believed to be safe in pregnancy and lowers the chance that you would need a Cesarean for genital sores at the time of labor. It also might lower the chance that the baby gets herpes. The medication is taken by mouth for the last month of pregnancy. </font></font>
Would you want to take this medication?

const.name: questionStart
const.value: Would you be willing to pay

module.const: <font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>

Preference Assessment: Rapid Test to Detect Herpes in Labor

An accurate test to detect herpes virus in the birth canal at the time of labor is available.
The test requires a swab of your vagina.
If the test reports that herpes is present in the birth canal you may be more likely to have a Cesarean delivery.
If offered, I would want my birth canal checked for herpes virus at the time of labor:
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>

Preference Assessment: Cesarean Delivery to Prevent Neonatal Herpes

Suppose that herpes is found in your birth canal while you are in labor.

<font face="Lucida Grande" size="+3">If there is a 1%-4% (1/100-4/100) chance that the baby will get herpes if delivered vaginally, would you proceed with vaginal delivery or would you prefer Cesarean delivery to lower the chance that the baby gets herpes? </font>
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>

Preference Assessment: Cesarean Delivery to Prevent Neonatal Herpes

Suppose that herpes is found in your birth canal while you are in labor.

<font face="Lucida Grande" size="+3">If there is a 50% (50/100) chance that the baby will get herpes if delivered vaginally, would you proceed with vaginal delivery or would you prefer a Cesarean delivery? </font>
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>

Please choose a response to the following statements:
I found the information in the presentation helpful.
I would recommend this presentation to my friends to learn more about herpes in pregnancy.
The presentation increased my anxiety about my pregnancy.

Thank you for your participation.


If you have questions or concerns regarding neonatal herpes, please contact the study coordinator or ask your prenatal provider.
<font face="Lucida Grande">This concludes the survey. You may now safely close this window.</font>
